_items.header_text: Would you like a coffee or a tea?
Would you like a coffee with milk?
Do you want sugar to your tea?

_items.body:
Throughout the world, more than six billion people consume milk and milk products. Over 750 million people live in dairy farming households.

Click to read more about milk

Coffee berries and their seeds undergo several processes before they become the familiar roasted coffee. Berries have been traditionally selectively picked by hand; a labor-intensive method, it involves the selection of only the berries at the peak of ripeness.

Click to read more about coffee

options.option_text: What does this course serve for?
How these functionalities can expand this tool?

_items.body: This course was made to test and present routing and unlocking posiibiloities of Adapt
This course was made with use of a adapt-dialogue component and adapt-unlocker plugin that were developed internally specially for this purpose

options.option_text: What does this course serve for?
How these functionalities can expand this tool?

_items.body:
Unlocker plugin enables quick developer solution for locking and unlocking any part of the course DOM structure on any event and condition. It can be used for unlocking menu items by making them appear on finished conditions or for conditional elements like pages or components
Dialogue plugin can display any HTML5 content on any dialogue option triggered on it by clicking, and thus enables creating comlplex interactions with unlimited amount of different routes.

options.option_text: What does this course serve for?

title: Our first look at a component
body: The earliest credible evidence of coffee-drinking appears in Yemen in southern Arabia in the middle of the 15th century in Sufi shrines. It was here in Arabia that coffee seeds were first roasted and brewed in a similar way to how it is now prepared. Coffee seeds were first exported from East Africa to Yemen, as the Coffea arabica plant is thought to have been indigenous to the former. Yemeni traders took coffee back to their homeland and began to cultivate the seed. By the 16th century, it had reached Persia, Turkey, and North Africa. From there, it spread to Europe and the rest of the world.

title: Our first look at a component
body: According to legend, ancestors of today's Oromo people in a region of Kaffa in Ethiopia were believed to have been the first to recognize the energizing effect of the coffee plant, though no direct evidence has been found indicating where in Africa coffee grew or who among the native populations might have used it as a stimulant or even known about it, earlier than the 17th century. The story of Kaldi, the 9th-century Ethiopian goatherd who discovered coffee when he noticed how excited his goats became after eating the beans from a coffee plant, did not appear in writing until 1671 and is probably apocryphal.

title: Our first look at a component
Our first look at a component
body: As an agricultural product, milk is extracted from non-human mammals during or soon after pregnancy. Dairy farms produced about 730 million tonnes of milk in 2011, from 260 million dairy cows. India is the world's largest producer of milk, and is the leading exporter of skimmed milk powder, yet it exports few other milk products. The ever increasing rise in domestic demand for dairy products and a large demand-supply gap could lead to India being a net importer of dairy products in the future. The United States, India, China and Brazil are the world's largest exporters of milk and milk products. China and Russia were the world's largest importers of milk and milk products until 2016 when both countries became self-sufficient, contributing to a worldwide glut of milk.

title: Our first look at a component

body:
The term 'milk' comes from 'Old English meoluc (West Saxon), milc (Anglian), from Proto-Germanic *meluks 'milk' (source also of Old Norse mjolk, Old Frisian melok, Old Saxon miluk, Dutch melk, Old High German miluh, German Milch, Gothic miluks)'.
Click here to view milk user guide
